The correct chronological order is option B: 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6 -> 7.
First, upbeat music plays over a black screen showing course information before the Evolution title appears. Then, the speaker states there was “no free oxygen” while listing H2, H2O, NH3, and CH4 in the early atmosphere. This is followed by a portrait of Aleksander Oparin appearing with his name captioned. Next, a portrait of John Haldane appears with his name captioned. On-screen text explains ‘coacervates’ absorbing organic compounds; the speaker discusses this and ends with a brief “hello”. Text cites Haldane’s ‘prebiotic soup’ and a solar-powered primordial sea; the speaker explains the idea. Finally, a title card “The Urey – Miller Experiment” appears as the speaker introduces it.

The correct chronological order of the events is option D: 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 5 -> 4 -> 6 -> 7 -> 8 -> 9.
First, we have event 1 where a photograph of Harold Urey appears, followed by event 2 where he describes his calculations. Then, event 3 mentions that the experiment confirmed key molecules of life could be synthesized on primitive Earth, which is related to the previous events. Event 4 notes that the view of a highly reducing early atmosphere was challenged toward the end of the 20th century, which may relate to the topic discussed in events 1-3.
Event 5 shows a diagram of the Miller-Urey apparatus, which is relevant to event 2 where amino acids were mentioned. Event 6 mentions meteorite analysis revealing similar compounds, which supports the idea that life emerged from space, as discussed in event 2.
Event 7 states that the first cellular forms arose about 2000 million years ago, which is relevant to event 3 where the origin of life was discussed. Finally, event 8 mentions that life arose from non-living molecules (abiogenesis), and event 9 credits roll over chimpanzee imagery while lively, cheerful folk
